bibl.title: Letter from Carroll Fox to [Hugh S. Cumming], January 4, 1924

div1.p: Fox submits his report on the rat flea survey. On the same page, Robertson adds a handwritten letter to Carter stating that the report is relatively uninteresting to him because there is no record of monthly catches of fleas which would take into account seasonal variations.

div1.head: Letter from Carroll Fox to [Hugh S. Cumming], January 4, 1924
div1.p:
COPY
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
United States
Public Health Service
Philadelphia, Pa.
January 4, 1924 Office of
Medical Officer in Charge
410 Chestnut St.
The Surgeon General
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Sir: (Attention Division Scientific Research)

In connection with the rat flea survey I have the honor to make
the following report on the results of the laboratory work up to
December 31, 1923.

Number of rats,- 1511 Number of fleas,-2532, as follows:
Ceratophyllus fasciatus------------1681
Xenopsylla cheopis----------------- 683
Ctenopsyllus musculi--------------- 104
Ctenocephalus canise--------------- 64

Summer
months and less
than New Orleans
winter Comms.
N.O did not have much
plague in Cerutin month
it I remember correctly
Average number of fleas per rat,-------1.7

Number of rats,- 1393 Number of fleas,- 1565, as follows:
Ceratophyllus fasciatus ------------971
Xenopsylla cheopis------------------572
Ctenopsyllus musculi---------------- 4
Ctenocephalus canis ---------------- 16
Ctenophthalmus sp.------------------ 2

A period of
13 months
of no value from
my point of view.
Average number of fleas per rat--------1.1

Number of Rats.- 1303 Number of fleas,- 2650, as follows:
Ceratophyllus fasciatus------------ 17
Xenopsylla cheopis-----------------1666
Ctenopsyllus musculi--------------- 949
Ctenocephalus canis---------------- 12
Xestopsylla gallinacea------------- 6

Fox told me that he thought the only
factor in the absence of Plague from the
North Atlantic Seaboard besides quarantine
was the absence of the rat flea (chiopis)
We had no quarantine until After 1911
Average number of fleas per rat,---------- 2.0
The number examined from Galveston remains unchanged from last report.

The report was sent me by Stimson you will
note at once that no record of monthly catches of
fleas is kept. Of course this makes the figures
relatively uninteresting to me, and shows that
Dr Fox and the Bureau do not consider the
seasonal prevalence of fleas of sufficient value
to record even when the catches are work.
I happen to know from weekly reports from Boston
in winter of 1922 & 23 that there was only about
one flea found to every 3 rats. If the yearly average
is 1.1, there is probably a period in Aug & Sept
when the number per rat is fairly high-say
nearly as high as the New Orleans winter count
(Nov - May) of 2 per rat. If seems that this
might have been made an interesting study
